author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Catharsis Songs
description: Big feelings, big playlist.
content: Welcome. A few weeks ago, I wrote about the release that songs like Taylor Swift’s “All Too Well (Taylor’s Version)” provide. I asked for your catharsis songs, the tracks that help you process big emotions, and you delivered. We’ve compiled the songs you sent into a Spotify playlist — check it out. The emails you sent accompanying your submissions were often cathartic themselves. Here’s a sampling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Senate Confirms Chris Magnus to Lead Customs and Border Protection
description: Mr. Magnus, the police chief in Tucson, Ariz., will seek to win the trust of the U.S. Border Patrol, an agency championed by former President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday approved President Biden’s choice to run Customs and Border Protection, filling a key post that has oversight of one of the president’s earliest and biggest challenges: handling the historic spike in illegal crossings at the nation’s southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Wrong Man Arrested Over Khashoggi Killing, France Says
description: The French authorities released a Saudi man who shared the name and age of a suspect in the murder of the dissident writer, saying it was a case of mistaken identity.
content: PARIS — French officials have freed a Saudi man a day after he was arrested on suspicion of links to the murder of the dissident Saudi writer Jamal Khashoggi, saying on Wednesday that it was a case of mistaken identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can the Press Prevent a Trump Restoration?
description: A journalism that shades the truth  for the sake of some higher cause will  lose the trust of some of the people it’s trying to steer away from demagogy.
content: There is a school of thought that holds that if Donald Trump sweeps back into power in 2024, or else loses narrowly but then plunges the United States into the kind of constitutional crisis he sought in 2020, the officially nonpartisan news media will have been an accessory to Trumpism. It will have failed to adequately emphasize Trump’s threat to American democracy, chosen a disastrous evenhandedness over moral clarity and covered President Biden (or perhaps Vice President Kamala Harris) like a normal politician instead of the republic’s last best hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Is There So Much Judgment About How We Feed Our Kids?
description: An interview with Priya Fielding-Singh, the author of “How the Other Half Eats.”
content: At a routine checkup for Priya Fielding-Singh’s newborn daughter, a well-meaning nurse put the child on a scale and said, “Let’s see how good of a job Mom is doing,” which was another way of asking whether the baby had gained weight from drinking Fielding-Singh’s breast milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Fieldston, the Bronx: A Private City Enclave Where Rocks Are the Stars
description: With its unique topography, tight zoning restrictions and sought-after schools, the neighborhood is ‘sort of suburban, but still part of the city.’
content: What might hinder an area’s development at one point in time can eventually make it stronger. Consider Fieldston, the affluent private neighborhood in the northwest corner of the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Greece: Seaside Splendor on Tinos Isle for $1.8 Million
description: Greeks increasingly see real estate as a safer investment than currencies or commodities, and ‘people are buying like there’s no tomorrow.’
content: This five-bedroom property sits on a hillside in Ktikados, a village near the southern coast of the Greek island of Tinos, in the Aegean Sea. Built in 2006 of local stone, the property has a main house with two bedrooms, plus two small guesthouses separated by a garden with olive and fruit trees, on just under half an acre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How The 2021 Holiday Gift Guide Came Together
description: It took about 40 people, dozens of testers, months of cooking and gaming and countless hours to curate this year’s list of items. And yes, there is a doughnut stool.
content: Big-box stores may be mocked for rolling out their Christmas decorations before Thanksgiving, but the team behind the 2021 Holiday Gift Guide is thinking about the holidays all year long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Here’s the latest on what courts have said about Biden’s vaccine mandates.
description: All three of President Biden’s vaccine mandates, , which are estimated to cover more than 100 million workers, have been put on hold by courts.
content: All three of President Biden’s broad vaccine mandates affecting the private sector have been put on hold by courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Pfizer’s Booster and Omicron.
description: The booster protects, and two shots may not be enough.
content: Pfizer and BioNTech said Wednesday that two doses of their Covid vaccine “may not be sufficient to protect against infection” by the new Omicron variant, but lab tests suggested that three doses offered significant protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Secret to This Glazed Holiday Ham? Root Beer.
description: The sarsaparilla flavor lends the meat a woodsy mintiness, which sings when it’s paired with aromatics like bay leaves and shallots.
content: I bought my father a record player for his 60th birthday. It’s a gray, retro-style Crosley standing on long black legs, like a whooping crane, looking out over our kitchen in Atlanta. I also included three starter records I knew he would love — “Crosby, Stills & Nash,” “Let It Be” and “Hotel California” — because they contain the signature songs he sang at karaoke my whole life. My father, the crooner, is always the life of the party, the class clown. My mother calls him a yes man, which she thinks means someone who says “yes” anytime he’s asked to hang out, which my father does. He loves fun, and as someone who also loves fun, I wanted him to have a record player for whenever his friends come over to play cards. Sometimes I can hear it in my dreams: John Lennon and Paul McCartney harmonizing over the clinking glasses of soju with lime juice from a plastic green bottle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: The Key to Marketing to Older People? Don’t Say ‘Old.’
description: To reach a rapidly expanding demographic, companies are changing their tone.
content: According to company lore, the idea for Nike’s CruzrOne sneaker — a well-cushioned, thick-soled running shoe that debuted in 2019 — originated with a conversation between a Nike designer, Tinker Hatfield, and the company’s co-founder Phil Knight. Mr. Hatfield made the mistake of congratulating Mr. Knight on his habit of walking eight miles a day and received a swift correction from his billionaire boss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Chance Encounters, Quitting and a Shower Bus
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about how a shower bus helps those without access, share about a chance encounter, reflect on when it’s good to quit, look closely at an intriguing photograph and write a story based on an illustration of a park bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Litsky
title: Darlene Hard, Strong-Willed Tennis Star Before Pro Era, Dies at 85
description: Hard, who was outspoken and independent minded, was the top-ranked American woman from 1960 to 1963.
content: Darlene Hard, a sturdy and strong-willed Californian with a power game who won 21 Grand Slam tennis championships as one of the last stars of the amateur era, died on Dec. 2 in Los Angeles. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Crypto Moguls Prepare for Capitol Hill
description: Six cryptocurrency chiefs will testify about the promises and perils of their industry.
content: Today, the chiefs of six cryptocurrency companies will testify before the House Financial Services Committee about the promises and perils of crypto assets. It’s the first time crypto executives have been summoned by lawmakers in this way, a sign of the industry’s maturity — and the risks that regulators see in its rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Meadows Sues Pelosi in Bid to Block Jan. 6 Committee Subpoena
description: The suit came hours after the committee said it would prepare a criminal contempt of Congress referral against Mark Meadows, who was President Donald J. Trump’s chief of staff on Jan. 6.
content: WASHINGTON — Mark Meadows, the former chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, filed suit on Wednesday against Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol in an attempt to persuade a federal judge to block the committee’s subpoenas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Four Takeaways From the 8th Day of Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial
description: A former pilot and a former assistant at Jeffrey Epstein’s Palm Beach home testified, as prosecutors sought to bolster the accounts of Ms. Maxwell’s accusers.
content: The jury in Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial heard from four government witnesses on Wednesday, including one of Jeffrey Epstein’s longtime pilots and the ex-boyfriend of one of Mr. Epstein’s accusers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: The F.D.A. authorizes AstraZeneca drug to protect people with immune problems.
description: The antibody drug, Evusheld, was found to be strongly effective in preventing Covid in a clinical trial that enrolled mostly those at high risk.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday authorized the first drug for widespread use in preventing Covid in Americans with weakened immune systems who have not been adequately protected by vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
title: Angela Merkel’s Political Life in Pictures: The End of an Era
description: Images from the former chancellor’s 16 years leading Germany, and from her life before.
content: BERLIN — When Angela Merkel became chancellor 16 years ago, George W. Bush was in the White House and Tony Blair was prime minister of Britain. There was no Twitter and no iPhone. Liberal democracy was in seemingly irreversible expansion, with the Orange Revolution having swept Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Yes, Americans Should Be Mailed Free Tests
description: We need every option available to return to normal.
content: The White House press secretary, Jen Psaki, responded with exasperation this week to a question about distributing at-home tests to Americans: “Should we just send one to every American?,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Who is Judge Regina Chu and who are the other key players in the Kimberly Potter trial?
description: Here are the key people who are part of the trial over the fatal shooting of Daunte Wright.
content: The trial of Kimberly Potter, the former police officer charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Daunte Wright during a traffic stop, is being streamed live on television and online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Luke Broadwater
title: Rally Planner With Ties to G.O.P. Is Cooperating in Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: Ali Alexander, who helped organize the gathering that drew Trump supporters to Washington on Jan. 6, could shed light on efforts by the former president and his allies to overturn the election.
content: Ali Alexander, a prominent organizer of Stop the Steal rallies with ties to far-right members of Congress who sought to invalidate the 2020 election results, is cooperating with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, pledging to deliver a trove of documents that could shed light on the activities that preceded the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Schools Are Closing Classrooms on Fridays. Parents Are Furious.
description: Desperate to keep teachers, some districts have turned to remote teaching for one day a week — and sometimes more. Families have been left to find child care.
content: DETROIT — Caitlin Reynolds, a single mother, was happy that her son, L.J., was finally settled into fourth grade after a rocky experience last year with remote learning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Ally, Member or Partner? NATO’s Long Dilemma Over Ukraine.
description: NATO promised Ukraine full membership in 2008, but without explaining how or when. Putin sees that promise as an ongoing threat to Russia.
content: BRUSSELS — Ukraine presents NATO with a dilemma many years in the making — one the alliance, itself, helped create.
source.name: The New York Times

title: International Suicide Prevention Helplines
description: If you or someone you know is having thoughts of suicide, help is available.
content: If you are having thoughts of suicide, speaking to someone can help. You are not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Jenny Gross
title: The Better.com C.E.O. says he’s ‘deeply sorry’ for firing workers over Zoom.
description: Vishal Garg said in a letter to employees on Tuesday that he had failed to show “respect and appreciation” in the call, which has been widely criticized.
content: The chief executive of the mortgage lender Better.com has apologized for the way he laid off about 900 employees over Zoom last week, saying that he “blundered the execution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caster Semenya
title: Caster Semenya on Maintaining Dignity and Hope in the Face of Oppression
description: Denied a spot in the 2020 Olympics, the South African gold medalist seeks justice in court.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: Are We Making Progress as a Planet? Teaching With The Times’s ‘Hindsight’ Series
description: In this lesson, students will look at promises of the past to gauge what progress has been made. Then, they will make predictions for the future.
content: Featured Series: “Hindsight,” beginning with a quiz from the introduction, “Dear People of 2021: What Can We Learn From Hindsight?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Pfizer and BioNTech say booster shots offer strong protection against Omicron.
content: Pfizer and BioNTech said three doses of their vaccine appear to offer significant protection against the fast-spreading Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Justo Gallego, Who Built a Cathedral, Brick by Brick, Dies at 96
description: A former monk, he spent decades constructing a grand edifice as an act of faith and devotion, and did so almost single-handedly.
content: MADRID — Justo Gallego, a former Spanish monk who devoted most of his life to building a cathedral almost single-handedly, with neither public funding nor support from his Roman Catholic Church, died on Sunday in that very building, on the outskirts of Madrid. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: The number of people quitting jobs remained near a record in October as openings increased.
description: The Labor Department said 4.2 million people quit their jobs in October, a decline of about 205,000 from September but still close to a record high.
content: Americans continued to leave their jobs in high numbers as the labor market grew hotter this fall, a sign the economy has maintained its momentum despite the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Training for Double Dutch at the Apollo’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about an annual double Dutch jump rope competition. Then, they will share about a game they love to play.
content: Featured Article: “Training for Double Dutch at the Apollo” by James Thomas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Standage
title: Does It Make Sense to Categorize People by Generation?
description: In “The Generation Myth,” Bobby Duffy deconstructs the stereotypes that have built up around millennials, boomers and other cohorts.
content: THE GENERATION MYTHWhy When You’re Born Matters Less Than You Think By Bobby Duffy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Won’t Let America Go. Can Democrats Pry It Away?
description: “The radicalized G.O.P. is the main anti-democratic force.”
content: Do you believe, as many political activists and theorists do, that the contemporary Republican Party poses a threat to democracy? After all, much of its current leadership refuses to accept the results of the 2020 presidential election and is dead set on undermining the concept of one person, one vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Big Question: Is the World of Work Forever Changed?
description: We asked a group of professionals from around the world to envision what working will look like in 2022 and beyond.
content: This article is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasmine Sanders
title: From Venus to Medusa, How Art Codifies the Objectification of Women
description: In “Women in the Picture,” the art historian Catherine McCormack traces classical female figures and their effects on Western culture.
content: WOMEN IN THE PICTURE What Culture Does With Female Bodies By Catherine McCormack
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Elizabeth Holmes rests her case in her fraud trial.
description: Lawyers must now agree on a set of jury instructions before closing arguments begin on Dec. 16.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — It lasted less than three weeks, centered on one person’s testimony and spanned topics such as financial projections, private jets, falsified documents and intimate-partner abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Crossed-Out Words
description: What message do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Peerless Imagination of Greg Tate
description: For four decades, he set the critical standard for elegantly intricate assessments of music, art, literature and more, writing dynamically about the resilience and paradoxes of Black creativity and life.
content: There are sentences, and then there are the writings of Greg Tate, who died on Tuesday at the age of 64. A critic and historian of music, art and so much more for over four decades, he was a singular voice, a fount of bravura essays on the fantastical creativity, determined resilience and wry paradoxes of Black creativity and life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: For the Giants, It’s Always Fourth-and-Too-Far
description: The Giants’ risk-averse offense may be as much to blame as injuries for the team’s 4-8 record.
content: It’s fourth-and-short in the opponent’s territory. Do you know what your head coach is doing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Sondheim Surge: Interest in His Work Soars After His Death
description: Fans have been streaming his music, buying his books, and trying to get in to see his shows, with a new revival of “Company” opening this week on Broadway.
content: Streams of Stephen Sondheim’s music are up more than 500 percent. New York’s Drama Book Shop sold out the first volume of his collected lyrics. And close to 5,000 people have been entering a lottery to win tickets to weekend performances for a sold-out run of “Assassins.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Congress gets a crash course on cryptocurrency.
description: For the first time, the chief executives of cryptocurrency companies faced questions from lawmakers about risk and regulation.
content: The chief executives of six cryptocurrency companies testified for nearly five hours on Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee about the promises and perils of cryptocurrencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Meg Stalter Rejoices With Dolly Parton and a Loyal Chihuahua
description: The comedian talks about banishing the worst of 2021 in Amazon’s “Yearly Departed,” while celebrating the best in real life.
content: Meg Stalter is famously her own biggest fan — if not you, then who? — but even she has been a little awed by her recent success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Won’t Send Top Officials to Beijing Winter Olympics
description: “There will be effectively a diplomatic boycott,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said of the decision to join the United States and others in registering discontent over human rights abuses in China.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Wednesday that there would be “effectively a diplomatic boycott” of the 2022 Beijing Olympics by Britain, which has now joined the United States and others in pulling its top officials from attendance of the Winter Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Hollywood Still Matters. These Actors Showed Why.
description: Even as theaters suffer, cinema has been thriving during the pandemic — thanks to the intimacy movies create between performer and audience.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Roving History of Mortals Considered Gods
description: “Accidental Gods,” by Anna Della Subin, is about “men unwittingly turned divine,” including Julius Caesar, Gandhi, Douglas MacArthur and others.
content: You might think that being worshiped as a god would be the ultimate dream come true — all that power and pageantry and extravagant adoration. But as I learned from Anna Della Subin’s “Accidental Gods,” what’s even more striking than the surprising frequency with which mortal men have been “unwittingly turned divine” is how often they tried to disavow their newfound exaltation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Japanese Billionaire Arrives at Space Station for 12-Day Tourist Trip
description: Yusaku Maezawa, the founder of the clothing retailer Zozo, will spend 12 days in orbit with a production assistant who will document his stay.
content: Yusaku Maezawa, a Japanese billionaire and fashion retail mogul, arrived at the International Space Station for a 12-day stay on Wednesday. He is the latest privately funded traveler to the orbital laboratory in a year that has seen more tourists making voyages to space than ever before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: 10 Ways I Fed My Fandom(s)
description: No apologies from our critic-at-large, who found plenty of movies, plays and TV series to nourish the culture nerd within.
content: It’s a great time to be a nerd — take it from me, a lifelong fangirl. Fandoms are one of the ways I mark a year across the spectrum of entertainment genres that I consume every day. Here’s my list of 10 favorite TV series, movies and plays that thrilled me as a comics nerd, pop culture nerd, literary nerd and drama nerd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Scientists Have a New Explanation for Mysterious Sand Spikes
description: New research links the geological oddities to intense ground shaking from earthquakes or asteroid impacts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: We’re Getting Close to ‘Universal’ Vaccines. It Hasn’t Been Easy.
description: A new class of flu vaccines could eventually save millions of lives — and perhaps stop the next pandemic — if scientists can overcome the remaining obstacles.
content: On Nov. 19, 2019, Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, happened to be describing to me recent research that was on his mind. “A real hot topic” at that moment, he said, was the development of a universal influenza vaccine. He meant a vaccine suitable for all ages that would be at least 75 percent effective for a year or more against Influenza A viruses — the type that causes pandemics but that also, along with Influenza B, annually infects as many as a billion people worldwide and kills somewhere between 290,000 to 650,000 of them. A push to develop such a vaccine began in earnest about a decade earlier and was gaining momentum. “That’s something that I’m spending a lot of time on,” he said. “Also, a lot of scientists are struggling in a positive way to make advances.” It was, he went on, “somewhat embarrassing” that a new and updated flu vaccine had to be made every year. “We really need to do much, much better to get a better vaccine. One that covers all of the possible iterations of influenza.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Who Wants to Be Governor of New York?
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s resignation has led to a rush of candidates from both parties declaring their intent to run for the state’s highest office.
content: The surprise resignation of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo instantly upended the 2022 governor’s race in New York, opening the floodgates for a rush of candidates vying for the state’s highest office after more than a decade with Mr. Cuomo at the helm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Climate Bill Includes Billions in Funding. Will It Be Spent Fairly?
description: The infrastructure measure funds programs that tend to favor wealthy, white communities.
content: The new infrastructure law signed by President Biden includes almost $50 billion to protect communities against climate change, the largest such investment ever. But, spending that money will test the president’s promise to pursue climate justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Neuman
title: De Blasio Fought for 2 Years to Keep Ethics Warning Secret. Here’s Why.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio was warned that he created an “appearance of coercion and improper access” by directly contacting donors who had business before the city.
content: When Bill de Blasio first took office as mayor of New York in 2014, he called two powerful real estate developers who had active projects in the city, and asked them to donate money to a nonprofit organization that he had created to advance his political agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: 10 Works of Art That Evaded the Algorithm This Year
description: Contemplation, not clicks: Our critic looks back on marble sculptures in Rome, songs of “atmospheric anxiety” and the Frick Collection in a new light.
content: The coronavirus pandemic is a health crisis with so many cultural sequelae: above all, the absorption of all facets of our lives deeper into networks and phone screens. Even more than last year, I’ve been drawn to art, music and movies that, in one way or another, evade the workings of likes and shares — and carve out a place for human creativity in a world too governed by algorithmic logic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Getting Married in the Metaverse
description: One couple’s recent nuptials in the virtual world known as the metaverse showcase the possibilities of having a wedding unfettered by the bounds of reality.
content: Traci and Dave Gagnon met in the cloud, so it only made sense that their wedding took place in it. On Labor Day weekend, the couple — or rather, their digital avatars — held a ceremony staged by Virbela, a company that builds virtual environments for work, learning and events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Will Forte Is Still Waiting for ‘MacGruber’ to Blow Up
description: In a new Peacock series, Forte returns as the unruly “Saturday Night Live” action hero who’s once again reckoning with bombs (including his 2010 movie).
content: To understand the duality of Will Forte, consider the following: This past July, Forte, the actor, writer and “Saturday Night Live” alumnus, married his wife, Olivia Modling, in an intimate weekend ceremony they organized, in part, to surprise Forte’s parents, who happened to be visiting them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California’s Reparations Task Force Meets Again
description: The first-in-the-nation effort is tackling fraught questions about who deserves payment and how much.
content: After the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, as the nation grappled with how to right a long history of wrongs, California took a momentous step in the name of racial equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The new government promises to be tougher on China and Russia.
description: Though its plans are aspirational for the moment, its commitments to Europe, NATO and the trans-Atlantic relationship are solid.
content: Germany’s new government is promising a tougher stance toward Russia and China, a change in mood music that will affect the rest of Europe, where Berlin has traditionally been the moderating voice and defined the center ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Proposal Would Allow E.U. to Retaliate Against Economic Pressure
description: The European Commission is considering sweeping powers to impose punitive sanctions on those seeking to influence its political policies through economic pressure.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union on Wednesday proposed new measures that would allow it to punish parties seeking to influence its political policies through economic pressure, like trade restrictions or the boycotting of European products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: The Year America Lost Its Democracy
description: Republicans mounted an all-out assault on voting rights. Democrats did little to stop them.
content: The foreign-policy journalist Joshua Keating used to write a series for Slate called “If It Happened There,” in which he reported on political and cultural developments in the United States in the tone of an American foreign correspondent sending dispatches from a nation on the other side of the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Being the Ricardos’ Review: Kiss, Fight, Rinse, Repeat
description: Nicole Kidman and Javier Bardem star as Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in Aaron Sorkin’s drama about one very bad week.
content: “I’m not funny,” Lucille Ball once said (LOL). “What I am is brave.” It was performative modesty of the kind that celebrities excel at. And it was true. You get the tiniest peek at how brave she could be in “Being the Ricardos,” Aaron Sorkin’s very soft look at a very bad week that Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz, had while starring in their show “I Love Lucy.” She was America’s favorite redhead, he was her glamorous bandleader husband, and they were adored by millions. But not everyone loved Lucy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A crucial Biden-Putin video call.
content: In a tense, two-hour video conference yesterday, President Biden warned Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader, that an invasion of Ukraine would result in heavy economic penalties for Russia and lead NATO to reposition its troops in Europe. It could also end Russia’s hopes of completing the Nord Stream II gas pipeline to Europe, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The World Is Unprepared for the Next Pandemic, Report Says
description: The latest Global Health Security Index finds that no country is positioned well to respond to outbreaks.
content: Nearly two years into the Covid-19 pandemic, the world remains “dangerously unprepared” for the next major outbreak, according to a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Frank Williams, Dominant Formula One Manager, Is Dead at 79
description: He overcame frequent adversity, including a near-fatal car accident, to become one of the most successful figures in motor sports history.
content: Frank Williams, a brash, hypercompetitive Formula One manager who overcame frequent personal and professional adversity to lead one of the most successful teams in the history of motor sports, died on Nov. 28 in Surrey, England. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Lawmakers Reach Deal to Overhaul How Military Handles Sexual Assault Cases
description: Under the agreement, commanders’ powers would be clipped after years of complaints about unfairness and retaliation.
content: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators reached a landmark agreement on Tuesday that would strip military commanders of most of their authority to prosecute sexual assaults and myriad other criminal cases, a move that Pentagon leaders, lawmakers and presidents have resisted for nearly a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: School District Investigates Claims of Longtime Sexual Misconduct by Teachers
description: Six teachers from Babylon High School have been placed on leave as the investigation continues and alumnae come forward with claims.
content: In late October, the school board in the bayside village of Babylon, on Long Island, sent out a letter that said an unidentified teacher had been removed from his post, pending an investigation into unspecified “disturbing allegations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn MacKeen
title: As Covid Deaths Rise, Lingering Grief Gets a New Name
description: Prolonged grief disorder was recently added to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, just as experts are predicting a coming wave of severe bereavement.
content: A year after her mother died from Covid, Fiana Garza Tulip held a small memorial service on a Texas beach that her family had visited countless times when she was a child. As she and her brother dropped a wreath of yellow roses into the waves, she expected to cry. But the tears did not come. She felt only guilt for appearing to be unmoved, heartless even.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: ‘Court Packing’ Issue Divides Commission Appointed by Biden
description: The bipartisan group voted 34 to 0 to send the president a report analyzing ideas like Supreme Court expansion, but it declined to take a stand.
content: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan commission appointed by President Biden to study possible changes to the federal judiciary unanimously approved a final report on Tuesday that flagged “profound disagreement” among its members over the issue that led to the panel’s creation: calls to expand or “pack” the Supreme Court with additional justices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Group Backed by Top Companies Moves to Combat A.I. Bias in Hiring
description: The organization has created a format for evaluating the technology, which is often used to screen job candidates.
content: Artificial intelligence software is increasingly used by human resources departments to screen résumés, conduct video interviews and assess a job seeker’s mental agility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: ‘The Snowy Day,’ a Children’s Classic, Becomes an Opera
description: Based on the popular 1962 children’s book, the show aims to celebrate Blackness and attract new audiences to the art form.
content: In the first scene of “The Snowy Day,” a new opera based on the popular 1962 children’s book, a Black mother sings an aria as her young son, Peter, prepares to go outdoors alone to explore the snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Colin Moynihan
title: Third Accuser Says Epstein and Maxwell Preyed on Her as a Troubled Teen
description: The accuser, who testified under her first name, Carolyn, described being preyed upon as an especially vulnerable child.
content: The 14-year-old girl was removing her clothing in the master bathroom of Jeffrey Epstein’s Palm Beach, Fla., home, preparing to give him a massage, she said, when Ghislaine Maxwell entered the room and touched her breasts, hips and buttocks. Ms. Maxwell told the teenager she had “a great body for Mr. Epstein and his friends,” the girl — now a woman in her 30s — told a jury Tuesday in Ms. Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Brooklyn Museum Gets a New President and Chief Operating Officer
description: Kimberly Panicek Trueblood will run the business side of an institution that has struggled financially and plans to refresh its building and galleries.
content: Just two weeks after receiving $50 million from the city to upgrade its building and modernize the galleries, the Brooklyn Museum on Wednesday announced that Kimberly Panicek Trueblood will be its new president and chief operating officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: The Achilles’ Heel of Biden’s Climate Plan? Coal Miners.
description: Unions representing other workers affected by climate legislation have struck deals, but opposition from coal miners has persisted, complicating the path to enactment.
content: For years, environmentalists have sought compromises with labor unions in industries reliant on fossil fuels, aware that one of the biggest obstacles to cutting carbon emissions is opposition from the unions’ members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
title: With Johnson Under Fire, Britain Introduces Tougher Covid Measures
description: People in England will be urged to work from home and have to show proof of vaccination. Critics say the prime minister is trying to deflect attention from a growing outcry over reports his staff flouted Covid rules.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Wednesday announced major new restrictions to curb the fast-spreading Omicron variant, reversing course on a long-held policy at a moment of acute political peril for him, with his staff accused of flouting the rules by holding an office party during last year’s lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Year on the Red Carpet
description: All that pent-up dressing up finally found an outlet. If it wasn’t a carpet per se, it was a public moment.
content: It was the year public figures crept back into the spotlight, first with a tiptoe out of doors at the presidential inauguration, then a socially distanced red carpet at the Oscars — and then a full throttle, ball-gowns-to-the-max explosion of pent-up dressing up at the Cannes Film Festival, as if to compensate for the previous year of enforced isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: copious
description: This word has appeared in 118 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: A Penny for Your Squats?
description: Among 52 incentives to exercise, giving people a 9-cent award if they returned to the gym after missing a workout helped the most.
content: Receiving a tiny monetary reward at the right moment could play an outsize role in motivating us to exercise, according to a large-scale and innovative new study of how to nudge people to show up at the gym.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Seligsohn
title: The U.S. and China Should Compete on This
description: Competition between American and Chinese companies will be the real driver of decreased greenhouse gas emissions around the globe.
content: If you are in the market for an electric vehicle today, there’s a good chance you’ll buy a Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: ‘Harry Potter’ Back Onstage, Streamlined and Still Magical
description: “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” returned to Broadway, now in one part instead of two. It may feel smaller, but is no less dazzling.
content: Like a lot of children, Harry Potter grew bigger as he got older. J.K. Rowling’s later novels in the series came in twice as thick, or more, as the first. The lengths of the film versions peaked with the adaptation of that final volume, “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” split into two parts running a combined four and a half hours. In 2018, “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” — an original play by Jack Thorne, based on a story by Thorne, Rowling and John Tiffany — opened on Broadway at the lavishly remodeled Lyric Theater. Also split in two, the total experience clocked in at more than five hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night: Putin and Biden’s Call Could Have Been an Email
description: The two-hour video call was a hot topic on late night Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘West Side Story’ Review: In Love and War, 1957 Might Be Tonight
description: Steven Spielberg rediscovers the breathing, troubling essence of a classic, building a bold and current screen musical with no pretense to perfection.
content: “West Side Story” sits near the pinnacle of post-World War II American middlebrow culture. First performed on Broadway in 1957 and brought to the screen four years later, it survives as both a time capsule and a reservoir of imperishable songs. What its creators attempted — a swirling fusion of literary sophistication and contemporary social concern, of playfulness and solemnity, of realism and fantasy, of street fighting and ballet — hadn’t quite been attempted before, and hasn’t been matched since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Orders Federal Vehicles and Buildings to Use Renewable Energy by 2050
description: Under an executive order, the federal government would phase out the purchase gasoline-powered vehicles and its buildings would be powered by wind, solar or other clean energy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday set in motion a plan to make the federal government carbon neutral, ordering federal agencies to buy electric vehicles, to power facilities with wind, solar and nuclear energy, and to use sustainable building materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Use Your Phone’s Privacy-Protection Tools
description: New settings in iOS 15 and Android 12 give you more power over your personal information and when (or if) apps and sites can see it.
content: Concerned about how your data is being used by apps and websites? Apple’s iOS 15 and Google’s Android 12 operating systems beefed up their privacy controls this year to give you more warnings — and options — when a site or service wants to use personal information like location or browser clicks. Here’s a quick guide to those settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Face Computers Are Coming. Now What?
description: Instead of letting Facebook or Apple decide the norms of this new technology, we need to do it.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: U.S. Threat to Squeeze Russia’s Economy Is a Tactic With a Mixed Record
description: Sanctions, like aiming to cut oil exports, could also hurt European allies. “It’s a limited toolbox,” one expert said.
content: LONDON — When Russian soldiers crossed into Ukraine and seized Crimea in 2014, the Obama administration responded with a slate of economic penalties that ultimately imposed sanctions on hundreds of Russian officials and businesses and restricted investments and trade in the nation’s crucial finance, oil and military sectors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Wary of Ban on State Aid to Religious Schools
description: The case, concerning a tuition program in Maine, seemed likely to extend a winning streak at the court for parents seeking public funds for religious education.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday seemed ready to take another step in requiring states to pay for religious education, with a majority of the justices indicating that they would not allow Maine to exclude religious schools from a state tuition program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: 60 Seconds With Aimee Lucido
description: A chat with one of the New York Times Crossword constructors.
content: PBJ, because it has saved me so many times when my first theme answer begins with a J and I need a three-letter word going down to end in that J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Coronavirus Cases Are Rising Among Children in South African Hospitals
description: The increase, observed in children’s wards at two major hospitals in South Africa, points to increased community transmission, doctors say.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The children had gone to the hospital for various reasons: One had jaundice, another malaria. A third had a broken bone. But once they were admitted, they all tested positive for the coronavirus, a worrying trend in South African hospitals that hints at how transmissible the new variant, Omicron, may be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Is There Still Sex in the City?’ Review: Candace Bushnell Dishes Hot Details
description: In her one-woman Off Broadway show, the “Sex and the City” author invites audiences behind the scenes of her life with a wink and a cocktail.
content: Like her “Sex and the City” alter ego, Carrie Bradshaw, Candace Bushnell dated a politician once — though he never asked her to pee on him. Dishy details like this are delightfully sprinkled throughout “Is There Still Sex in the City?,” a one-woman show written by and starring Bushnell that opened on Tuesday at the Daryl Roth Theater. But she offers more here than mere fodder for fans of her conflicted urban fairy tale of female sexual liberation, which grew from her mid-’90s column for The New York Observer into the enduring franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Ukraine, Explained
description: And why people are fearing war there.
content: If you were a foreign leader hostile to the United States — sitting in, say, Moscow or Beijing — how would you view the U.S. today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Amid new U.K. restrictions, the government is accused of flouting rules last Christmas.
description: Critics have condemned a recording showing the prime minister’s staff joking about breaches of coronavirus restrictions last year, when Britain was in lockdown.
content: LONDON — For a week, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has denied damaging claims that his staff broke lockdown rules by holding a party last Christmas when such festivities were banned under government-imposed coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Coronavirus Attacks Fat Tissue, Scientists Find
description: The research may help explain why people who are overweight and obese have been at higher risk of severe illness and death from Covid.
content: From the start of the pandemic, the coronavirus seemed to target people carrying extra pounds. Patients who were overweight or obese were more likely to develop severe Covid-19 and more likely to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jere Hester
title: ‘Improvise It, Man.’ How to Make Magic Like the Beatles.
description: In a new documentary, ‘Get Back,’ the Beatles give a master class in creativity under pressure.
content: Paul McCartney is stressing out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Fatal Distraction’ Review: Parents Go Through the Unthinkable
description: In the documentary by Susan Morgan Cooper, a father is on trial after his baby dies in the back seat of a hot car.
content: On the morning of June 18, 2014, Justin Ross Harris and his wife, Leanna, were the adoring parents of a 22-month-old son, Cooper. By the end of the day, their child was dead. Harris forgot to drop off his son at day care, and instead drove to work, leaving Cooper in the back seat, where the child died in the Georgia heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: A Diplomatic Boycott Is a Start. Sponsors Should Act Next.
description: The U.S. has announced a diplomatic boycott of the Beijing Winter Olympics, but corporations have been glaringly quiet about human rights in China.
content: The decision by President Biden to have his administration steer clear of the Beijing Winter Olympics is not enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Fashion Institute of Technology Will Open a Social Justice Center
description: With nearly $4 million in funding, the school wants to build a pipeline of diverse fashion talent from middle school to the C-suite.
content: Change takes time: That was the sentiment underlying many corporate responses in the wake of George Floyd’s murder in 2020, as the fashion industry, among others, faced new calls for systemic change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus
title: Defector Helps Build Case Against Belarus Over Ryanair Flight It Forced Down
description: A former air traffic controller has been telling Polish investigators what he knows about the diversion of the plane carrying a Belarus dissident in May.
content: WARSAW — This summer, as Polish guards repelled migrants trying to cross their country’s eastern border with Belarus, one man who slipped furtively into Poland received a warm but top-secret welcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty and Julie Creswell
title: The Era of the Celebrity Meal
description: Fast-food chains are hungry for celebrity partners to drive sales and appeal to younger consumers. The method is working.
content: On a Friday afternoon in the spring of 2020, Hope Bagozzi, the chief marketing officer at the Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons, was on a Zoom call with representatives for Justin Bieber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Omicron, Instagram, Great Performers: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Arlene Shuler to Step Down as President of New York City Center
description: Shuler, a former dancer, has run the theater since 2003, instituting its popular Fall for Dance series.
content: Arlene Shuler, the president and chief executive of New York City Center, a historic home for dance that hosts the accessible and popular Fall for Dance festival, has announced that she will step down at the end of the 2021-22 season this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Pearl Harbor and the Capacity for Surprise
description: Could we avert a similar catastrophe in the future?
content: It’s a shame that the 80th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor received so little public attention. We are living in an era that holds some unpleasant resemblances to the period before the Japanese attack. And we are losing the capacity for surprise that could help us anticipate or avert a similar catastrophe in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: The Best Science Fiction and Fantasy Books of 2021
description: From epic voyages to haunting folk tales, here are the highlights of an otherworldly year.
content: In the gray fog of an uncertain year, these books stand out in bright colors and floods of intense feeling. They’re organized only by the order in which I read them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Safety agency says it is looking into Tesla video games that can be played while moving.
description: “We are aware of driver concerns and are discussing the feature with the manufacturer,” the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said in a statement.
content: The federal government’s top auto safety regulator said on Wednesday that it had begun looking into a new feature in Tesla cars allowing drivers to play video games on a large touch-screen while the vehicles are moving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods Set to Play the PNC Championship With His Son
description: The golfer, who is still recovering from a serious car crash in February, has not competed in a tournament since he and his son, Charlie, last played in the family team event a year ago.
content: Last week, Tiger Woods was emphatic that he would never again be a full-time player on the PGA Tour because of the serious leg injuries he sustained in a high-speed car crash in February. But Woods conceded that he could “play a round here and there,” which he called, “a little hit and giggle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.9 Million Homes in Connecticut, South Carolina and Illinois
description: A waterfront house in Westport, an 1843 home in Charleston and a four-bedroom townhouse in Chicago.
content: This house was conceived to take advantage of the property’s more than 100-foot frontage along Sherwood Mill Pond, with water views from almost every room; the architect, Roger Bartels, was recognized by the Home Builders and Remodelers Association of Connecticut for his design. The house is a few miles from Sherwood Beach, a public beach at Sherwood Island State Park, where there are designated places to fish and swim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: After Warm Start to Snow Season, Colorado Resorts Look for Relief
description: Record high temperatures have left mountain resorts across the state reliant on artificial snow. Winter storms predicted for this week could change that.
content: An unusually warm and dry start to Colorado’s snow season has left many of the state’s mountain resorts wholly dependent on artificial snow, to the growing frustration of winter sports enthusiasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Who was Daunte Wright?
description: Mr. Wright, who was killed by an officer during a traffic stop, had been trying to improve his life for his young son, according to those who knew him.
content: Daunte Wright has been remembered by friends as upbeat and gregarious, someone who loved to play basketball and was a supportive father to his son, Daunte Jr., who was a year old when Mr. Wright, 20, was killed by a police officer during a traffic stop.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Shops and Salons, Mixed Feelings Over New York City Vaccine Mandate
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 8, 2021.
content: “I hate the point when they’re like, OK, you have to get vaccinated or you are getting fired. But also, hey, you’re going to bring a virus and infect everybody in the job.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Annotated by the Author: ‘Meet “Supergirl,” the World’s Strongest Teenager’
description: Corey Kilgannon, a Times journalist known for his profiles, tells us how to use quotes, description and detail to show what is unique about a person.
content: To support our new Profile Contest, we asked Corey Kilgannon, a Pulitzer Prize-winning Metro reporter, to create this edition of Annotated by the Author, our Mentor Text series in which we invite Times journalists to comment on their writing processes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Supreme Court Faces a Voting Paradox
description: Any voting system is vulnerable to inconsistency.
content: There is a chance — not a likelihood, but a chance — that the decision the Supreme Court reaches on abortion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization will be confusing, inconsistent and even paradoxical. If so, it might not be the fault of the court. It could be because of an inherent problem in voting procedures — all possible voting procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple can delay changes to App Store rules, appeals court says.
description: The ruling was a win for Apple, which can put off tweaking its App Store policies until its legal battle with Epic Games concludes.
content: A federal appeals court delivered a last-minute reprieve to Apple on Wednesday, agreeing to the company’s request to delay a legal order requiring it to make policy changes to its App Store that could help app developers circumvent what they say are unfair fees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Lawmakers urge the head of Instagram to better protect children.
description: Adam Mosseri, the company’s leader, was asked to appear before a Senate panel after internal research leaked that said the app had a toxic effect on some teenagers.
content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers of both parties came out swinging in a hearing on Wednesday with Adam Mosseri, the head of Instagram, expressing deep skepticism and anger toward the company for not doing enough to protect young users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: On the Citizen App, Even the Happy Videos Can Be Unsettling
description: However the “personal safety” app adapts its message, it’s still toying with how you feel about your own community.
content: The “personal safety” app Citizen recently sent me a heartwarming — aspirationally heartwarming, anyway — short video. I’d been using the app for about a month, during which it fed me all kinds of alerts on happenings nearby: Four Gunshots Heard. Two Men Fighting. Report of Woman With Box Cutter Making Threats. For some, Citizen had attached videos taken by other users, mostly boring shots of police cars and ambulances clustered by the sides of roads. But this video, titled “Missing Teenage Girl Found,” was different. There were amateur phone clips, yes, but also animated graphics and voice-over narration. The video told a story, and it gave Citizen the starring role.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Roman Art to the Sri Lankan Civil War
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: TWELVE CAESARS: Images of Power From the Ancient World to the Modern, by Mary Beard. (Princeton University, $35.) This deeply researched account explores how Roman art has shaped the Western world’s understanding of power for two millenniums, from ancient Roman imperial portraits to the work of the 19th-century American sculptor Edmonia Lewis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Sheriff Who Took on Andrew Cuomo
description: Craig Apple Sr. filed a criminal complaint against the former governor in October. He has a progressive record that is unusual for a county sheriff.
content: It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll meet the sheriff who charged former Gov. Andrew Cuomo with a misdemeanor sex crime. We’ll also see a piano that Thomas Edison sank his teeth into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Krupke, Rachelle Bonja, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Why Ukraine Matters to Vladimir Putin
description: Amid fears that Moscow is preparing for an invasion, one thing is clear: The Russian president has a singular fixation on the former Soviet republic.
content: The Russian military is on the move toward the border with Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Serena Williams Withdraws From Australian Open
description: Williams, 40, announced she would skip her second straight Grand Slam event, saying, “I am not where I need to be physically to compete.”
content: Serena Williams has announced her withdrawal from next month’s Australian Open, extending her absence from the sport that she long ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Do Active Shooter Drills Work?
description: They may harm the mental health of students, while doing little to prevent mass shootings.
content: Today, three questions: Do active shooter drills work? What are pediatricians worrying about most right now? And how do teenage girls adjust to their changing bodies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Mujib Mashal
title: India’s Top Military General Dies in Helicopter Crash
description: Gen. Bipin Rawat, who was killed along with his wife and 11 others on board, was in charge of overhauling a military that has struggled to modernize.
content: NEW DELHI — Gen. Bipin Rawat, India’s highest-ranking military official, leading efforts to modernize the country’s armed forces, died in a helicopter crash on Wednesday along with his wife and 11 others, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: Chanel Celebrates Craft, and Cardigans
description: The brand’s annual Métiers d’Art show went on, despite controversy.
content: PARIS — Few Chanel customers have probably ever ventured to the industrial fringes of the 19th Arrondissement in the northeast of Paris. But on Dec. 7, they found themselves blinking in the frigid December fog at Place Skanderberg, just outside the Périphérique ring road, waiting for the brand’s annual Métiers d’Art show to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Michael Hurley, an Original Folk Iconoclast, Turns 80
description: For six decades, the folk singer has chronicled his woes and loves on records he’s mostly made himself. His new album celebrates that independence — and the community it fostered.
content: When the singer-songwriter Michael Hurley was 24, Moe Asch handed him $100 and told him to go make his second album. They never spoke again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: David Banks, Educator and Adams Ally, Is Next N.Y.C. Schools Chancellor
description: Mr. Banks, who founded the Eagle Academy, a network of public schools for boys, is the first commissioner named to Mayor-elect Eric Adams’s administration.
content: David C. Banks, a longtime New York City educator who rose to prominence after creating a network of public all-boys schools, has been chosen by Mayor-elect Eric Adams to be the next chancellor of New York City’s public school system, the nation’s largest, according to several people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liza Weisstuch
title: These Books Stand the (Silly, Messy, Topsy-Turvy) Test of Time
description: Mr. Men Little Miss, the children’s book series created by Roger Hargreaves, turns 50 this year.
content: In the world of Mr. Men and Little Miss, things are exactly what they seem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Davidson
title: I’m an E.R. Doctor in Michigan, Where Unvaccinated People Are Filling Hospital Beds
description: With every shift, I see the strain people sick with Covid-19 put on my hospital.
content: Recently a patient in his 70s came seeking care at the small rural hospital in West Michigan where I’ve worked as an emergency physician for two decades. He had tested positive for the coronavirus earlier in the week, was running a high fever and struggled to breathe. When asked if he’d been vaccinated, he snapped back, “I don’t approve of the vaccine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Here are the charges that Kimberly Potter faces.
description: The police officer who shot and killed Mr. Wright during a traffic stop faces two felony counts; both are for manslaughter, not murder.
content: The criminal complaint filed by prosecutors in Hennepin County, Minn., lists two criminal counts against the defendant, Kimberly Potter, a police officer, in connection with the fatal shooting of Daunte Wright during a traffic stop in Brooklyn Center in April. Both counts are felonies, but neither is a murder charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexey Kovalev
title: The Pandemic Is Beating Putin
description: The virus has starkly revealed the limits of the president’s power.
content: A deadly virus can’t be ignored, jailed, exiled or co-opted — nor can it be locked down without great economic cost. That puts President Vladimir Putin of Russia in a bind. The pandemic, perhaps his hardiest foe to date, has starkly revealed the limits of his power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: When Have You Made the Best of a Difficult Situation?
description: A group of people recently got stranded at a pub during a snowstorm and called it a “life-changing experience.” Have you ever faced something unpleasant with a positive attitude?
content: Late last month, a snowstorm stranded guests, employees and an Oasis tribute band at a pub in Yorkshire, England. They were stuck in the pub, which is also an inn, for three days until the roads were cleared and it was safe for them to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Can an Athlete’s Blood Enhance Brainpower?
description: Scientists who injected idle mice with blood from athletic mice found improvements in learning and memory. The findings could have implications for Alzheimer’s research and beyond.
content: What if something in the blood of an athlete could boost the brainpower of someone who doesn’t or can’t exercise? Could a protein that gets amplified when people exercise help stave off symptoms of Alzheimer’s and other memory disorders?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Fox News Christmas Tree Is Set on Fire in Manhattan
description: The 50-foot tree had been ceremonially lit days earlier during a broadcast. The police said that a man was in custody in connection with the blaze.
content: A man was arrested on Wednesday and charged with setting fire to a 50-foot-tall artificial Christmas tree outside the Fox News headquarters in New York City, prompting a race to extinguish the blaze in the early morning hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Right on the Map
description: Philip Koski makes his New York Times debut.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — A P.S.A. for crossword constructors: If you keep putting cute animals in your grids, I’ll keep putting pictures of them in my columns. I need only the flimsiest excuse to spend hours searching photo databases for puppies and kittens and whatever other floofy creatures you decided to use as fill. So please, for all our sakes, keep doing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
title: Merkel Departs, Opening a New Chapter for Germany and Europe
description: After 16 years, Angela Merkel handed over the German chancellery to Olaf Scholz, leaving behind a changed country and a polarizing legacy.
content: BERLIN — It was vintage Angela Merkel: The woman who has dominated European politics for the better part of two decades handed over her office to the next German chancellor, thanked her staff, then walked to the door and made an exit — her final one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: The Oscars Are Broken. Here’s How to Fix Them.
description: The ratings flop that was the last ceremony provided useful lessons in what not to do. But there are steps the academy can take for an actually enjoyable evening.
content: His client was having a great night. He should have been thrilled. But on the last Sunday night in April, as this year’s dire Oscar ceremony continued to deflate, a top Hollywood representative texted me about the “beyond terrible” show and fretted, “The entire country has tuned out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Manatees, Facing a Crisis, Will Get a Bit of Help: Extra Feeding
description: In a first, wildlife officials have decided to provide food for the mammals, which have suffered catastrophic losses in Florida waters over the last year.
content: The starving manatees are easy enough to spot. You can see their ribs through their skin. They surface to breathe more than normal. Those most in need appear off balance, listing to one side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Just in Time for Christmas: Knitwear Fit for a T. Rex
description: The Natural History Museum in London outfitted its animatronic Tyrannosaurus rex in a colorful Christmas sweater.
content: Behold the fearsome Tyrannosaurus rex — all swaddled in a cozy Christmas sweater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Some Jan. 6 Rioters May Use Police Brutality as a Defense
description: Half a dozen defendants in the assault on the Capitol are using video to try to make a case that they were simply protecting themselves and others. They face skepticism and an uphill legal battle.
content: With the first trials connected to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol set to begin early next year, defense lawyers have started in earnest to road test strategies for defeating the government’s charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Greg Tate, Influential Critic of Black Culture, Dies at 64
description: His writing for The Village Voice and other publications helped elevate hip-hop and street art to the same planes as jazz and Abstract Expressionism.
content: Greg Tate, a journalist and critic whose articles for The Village Voice, Rolling Stone and other publications starting in the 1980s helped elevate hip-hop and street art to the same plane as jazz and Abstract Expressionism, died on Tuesday in New York City. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Sublime Spectacle of Yoko Ono Disrupting the Beatles
description: In Peter Jackson’s “The Beatles: Get Back,” Ono is a performance artist at the height of her powers.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Is the University of Austin Just a PR Stunt?
description: Can a new university fix academia’s problems? Or will it just create another ideological bubble?
content: A group of scholars and journalists announced last month that they were founding the University of Austin on the belief that free speech is being stifled on college campuses across America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: How Tech Is Helping Poor People Get Government Aid
description: Even as the government expanded aid programs, many people faced barriers to using them. That problem is now being addressed with apps and streamlined websites.
content: WASHINGTON — In making his case that safety net programs should be easier to use, Jimmy Chen, a tech entrepreneur, recalled visiting a welfare office where people on food stamps endured long waits to submit routine paperwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Are You Optimistic About the Future?
description: A new global survey shows that many say children today will be less economically successful than their parents. Are you surprised?
content: Will today’s children be better off financially than their parents?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Mark Guarino
title: Jury in Jussie Smollett Trial Begins Deliberations
description: After closing arguments on Wednesday, the panel began considering whether the actor had staged a hate crime against himself, as the two men who attacked him have testified.
content: The jury tasked with deciding whether Jussie Smollett falsely told the police that he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic assault began deliberations on Wednesday and started to grapple with the two differing narratives of what happened on a freezing Chicago night in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Pastor Leaves His Church After Appearing on HBO Drag Show
description: A United Methodist Church pastor in Indiana stepped down after performing in drag and speaking about inclusion on the show “We’re Here.”
content: When Pastor Craig Duke stepped onstage in a small town in southern Indiana, wearing a cotton-candy-pink wig and a sparkly dress under his white robe, he knew his performance would rile some members of his congregation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: California Positions Itself as a ‘Refuge’ of Abortion Rights
description: A new legislative proposal includes the recommendation to fund the procedure for low-income women who come to California for abortion services.
content: Political leaders in California said on Wednesday that they would work to make the state a sanctuary for women seeking abortions if a Supreme Court ruling allows the procedure to be banned in more conservative parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao, Jeff Kao and Gray Beltran
title: Beijing Silenced Peng Shuai in 20 Minutes, Then Spent Weeks on Damage Control
description: Chinese propaganda officials have tried to shape the global discussion of the tennis player Peng Shuai’s #MeToo accusations, but their top-down strategy has largely stumbled.
content: Chinese propaganda officials have tried to shape the global discussion of the tennis player Peng Shuai’s #MeToo accusations, but their top-down strategy has largely stumbled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MITCH SMITH
title: Bob Dole Through His Hometown’s Eyes
description: Dole felt deeply indebted to Russell, Kan., where reminders of his legacy are everywhere.
content: Dole felt deeply indebted to Russell, Kan., where reminders of his legacy are everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Stirone
title: Moon Cube and Mysteries of the Solar System
description: A Chinese lunar rover spotted an unusual object on the moon's surface. Extraterrestrial artifact, or the latest case of mistaken space identity?
content: A Chinese lunar rover spotted an unusual object on the moon's surface. Extraterrestrial artifact, or the latest case of mistaken space identity?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Morello
title: Radical Passion is a Family Matter for Me and My 98-year-old Mom
description: She taught me that justice is more important than unity, and that unconditional love and support is a pretty sound parenting baseline.
content: She taught me that justice is more important than unity, and that unconditional love and support is a pretty sound parenting baseline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seaside Splendor in the Greek Isles
description: This seaside five-bedroom compound on the Greek island of Tinos, with a main house and two residential outbuildings, is for sale for $1.8 million.
content: This seaside five-bedroom compound on the Greek island of Tinos, with a main house and two residential outbuildings, is for sale for $1.8 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Fieldston
description: With its unique topography, tight zoning restrictions and sought-after schools, the neighborhood is ‘sort of suburban, but still part of the city.’
content: With its unique topography, tight zoning restrictions and sought-after schools, the neighborhood is ‘sort of suburban, but still part of the city.’
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.9 Million
description: A waterfront house in Westport, Conn.; an 1843 home in Charleston, S.C.; and a four-bedroom townhouse in Chicago.
content: A waterfront house in Westport, Conn.; an 1843 home in Charleston, S.C.; and a four-bedroom townhouse in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Try a comforting, creamy orzo recipe from Melissa Clark and a wintry menu from David Tanis.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark is in the newspaper we delivered to the vicinity of our subscribers’ front doors this morning, with a new recipe for what she’s calling brown-butter orzo with butternut squash (above). It’s a lovely, one-pot affair, rich and creamy and almost risottolike in consistency: Sweet and velvety squash takes well to a dollop of cooling ricotta against the heat of red-pepper flakes and a zip of lemon, a near-perfect rejoinder to the chill and damp of a December evening. Maybe you could give it a try tonight? Fortifying!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Casting Blame Amid the Covid Crisis
description: Readers discuss Bret Stephens’s call for an end to “Covid blame games.” Also: Overdose deaths; access to birth control; reducing gun violence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 8, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 8, 2021.
content: The coronavirus update map published on several recent Sundays showed incorrect case figures for two regions of Alaska that report their data together. On Nov. 12, Bristol Bay, Lake and Peninsula Boroughs had 50 to 75 cases per 100,000 people, not more than 100 per 100,000. On Nov. 5, 12 and 19, Yakutat City and Borough, Hoonah-Angoon Census Area had 25 to 50 cases per 100,000 people, not more than 100 per 100,000. And on Oct. 29, Yakutat City and Borough, Hoonah-Angoon Census Area had fewer than 25 cases per 100,000 people, not more than 100 per 100,000. The correct map can be viewed at nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times
